questions.text: A 45-year-old woman presents with progressive palmoplantar, nose & pinna pigmentation. Urine sample collected for Benedict’s test changes to black in the supernatant and the test gives greenish brown precipitate. What is the diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Alkaptonuria

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Alkaptonuria is characterized by the accumulation of homogentisic acid, leading to black urine upon standing and progressive skin pigmentation, and is caused by a deficiency in homogentisate dioxygenase .
  • ➤ homogentisate dioxygenase

questions.text: The type of enzyme inhibition in which Succinate dehydrogenase reaction is inhibited by malonate is an example of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Competitive

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Competitive Inhibitors of Enzymes
  • ➤ Competitive Inhibitors of Enzymes
  • ➤ Some Competitive Inhibitors Which Are Not Drugs

questions.text: A tRNA molecule that is supposed to carry cysteine (tRNAcys) is mischarged so that it actually carries alanine (ala-tRNAcys). Assuming no correction occurs, what will be the fate of this alanine residue during protein synthesis?

options.label: A
options.text: It will be incorporated into a protein in response to an alanine codon

options.label: B
options.text: It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon

options.label: C
options.text: It will remain attached to the tRNA as it cannot be used for protein synthesis

options.label: D
options.text: It will be chemically converted to cysteine by cellular enzymes

questions.correct_answer: B. It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It will be incorporated into a protein in response to a cysteine codon.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When a tRNA molecule is mischarged, the amino acid attached (even if incorrect) will be incorporated into the protein according to the tRNA's anticodon, not the amino acid attached. Therefore, alanine will be added in response to a cysteine codon in this case.

questions.text: The base sequence of the strand of DNA used as the template for transcription has the base sequence GATCTAC. What is the base sequence of RNA product?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GUAGAUC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To obtain the RNA sequence from a DNA template strand, first generate the complementary DNA strand (non-template), and then replace thymine (T) with uracil (U) in the RNA strand.

questions.text: A 7-month-old baby was diagnosed with urea cycle disorder. Past history indicates the same disease in a previous baby who died at 1 year of age. What could be the rationale for feeding benzoic acid to subjects with a urea cycle enzyme defect?

options.label: A
options.text: It provides an alternative route for nitrogen excretion through glycine conjugate, hippuric acid

options.label: B
options.text: It provides an alternative route for nitrogen excretion through N-acetylglucuronic acid conjugate kynurenine

options.label: D
options.text: It neutralizes ammonia in both blood and urine

questions.correct_answer: A. It provides an alternative route for nitrogen excretion through glycine conjugate, hippuric acid
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) It provides an alternative route for nitrogen excretion through glycine conjugate, hippuric acid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Benzoic acid provides an alternative route for nitrogen excretion by converting nitrogen to hippuric acid via conjugation with glycine , which is then excreted in the urine. This helps to lower ammonia levels in patients with urea cycle disorders.
  • ➤ hippuric acid
  • ➤ glycine

questions.text: Which is the most probable diagnosis with reference to the below clinical features?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Familial Hypercholesterolemia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tendon xanthomas are a hallmark of familial hypercholesterolemia , a condition caused by defects in the LDL receptor or apo B100 , leading to high cholesterol levels and cholesterol deposition in tendons.
  • ➤ familial hypercholesterolemia
  • ➤ LDL receptor
  • ➤ apo B100

questions.text: Children with autism and other disorders with mental disability are often put on megavitamin supplements despite no scientific evidence of benefit. Although most vitamins are harmless in excess, merely being excreted in urine, vitamin A can be toxic. All of the following are symptoms of either chronic or acute vitamin A toxicity except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Xerophthalmia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: A neonatal examination was done in a newborn girl baby. On examination, the baby has blue eyes, blonde hair, and fair skin. Test result shows positive Guthrie test. All are true except:

options.label: C
options.text: White patch of hair due to tryptophan

questions.correct_answer: C. White patch of hair due to tryptophan
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) White patch of hair due to tryptophan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Phenylketonuria , the deficiency in phenylalanine hydroxylase leads to hypopigmentation due to reduced tyrosine and melanin, and metabolites such as phenylacetate are present in the urine. The white patch of hair is due to tyrosine deficiency , not tryptophan.
  • ➤ Phenylketonuria
  • ➤ phenylalanine hydroxylase
  • ➤ tyrosine deficiency

questions.text: A 3-year-old girl presents with progressive muscle weakness, myopathy, and hepatomegaly. Upon investigation, a skeletal muscle biopsy reveals abnormal glycogen accumulation with very long outer branches. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis for this patient's condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Anderson disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Anderson disease is characterized by abnormal glycogen accumulation with long outer branches due to a deficiency of the branching enzyme , leading to progressive muscle weakness, myopathy, and hepatomegaly.
  • ➤ long outer branches
  • ➤ branching enzyme

questions.text: Which of the following is a true statement regarding the inhibitors in this graph?

options.label: A
options.text: Inhibitor A decreases the affinity of enzyme for substrate

options.label: B
options.text: Inhibitor B decreases the affinity of enzyme for substrate

options.label: C
options.text: Inhibitor A decreases the Vmax of the enzyme

options.label: D
options.text: Inhibitors A and B have no effect on enzyme kinetic parameters

questions.correct_answer: A. Inhibitor A decreases the affinity of enzyme for substrate
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Inhibitor A decreases the affinity of enzyme for substrate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ In competitive inhibition, Km increases (decreasing affinity), while Vmax remains unchanged. In non-competitive inhibition, Vmax decreases, but Km remains unchanged.
  • ➤ Km
  • ➤ Vmax
  • ➤ Vmax
  • ➤ Km

questions.text: A 30-year-old male presents with enlarged, yellow-orange tonsils and reports intermittent episodes of neuropathy. Which of the following is a characteristic finding in his plasma lipoprotein profile?

options.label: C
options.text: Absent or extremely low HDL cholesterol

questions.correct_answer: C. Absent or extremely low HDL cholesterol
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Absent or extremely low HDL cholesterol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Tangier disease is characterized by the absence or extremely low levels of HDL cholesterol and presents with yellow-orange tonsils, neuropathy, and lipid metabolism abnormalities due to an ABCA1 mutation .
  • ➤ Tangier disease
  • ➤ absence or extremely low levels of HDL cholesterol
  • ➤ ABCA1 mutation

questions.text: A 25-year-old female presents with chronic fatigue, easy bruising, and hepatosplenomegaly. On bone marrow examination, cells with a characteristic appearance as shown in the image below are observed. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for her condition?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Beta Gluco-cerebrosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Gaucher’s disease is caused by a deficiency in beta-glucocerebrosidase , leading to the accumulation of glucocerebroside and characteristic Gaucher cells in tissues. This manifests as hepatosplenomegaly, fatigue, and easy bruising.
  • ➤ Gaucher’s disease
  • ➤ beta-glucocerebrosidase
  • ➤ Gaucher cells

questions.text: A newborn presents with a distinctive sweet odor in the urine and shows signs of poor feeding and lethargy within a few days after birth. Which of the following biochemical abnormalities are characteristic of this infant's condition?

options.label: B
options.text: Presence of α-keto acids in the urine

options.label: D
options.text: Presence of homogentisic acid in urine

questions.correct_answer: B. Presence of α-keto acids in the urine
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Presence of α-keto acids in the urine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ In Maple Syrup Urine Disease , there is an accumulation of branched-chain amino acids and their corresponding α-keto acids , which can be detected in the blood and urine, producing a sweet, maple syrup-like odor.
  • ➤ Maple Syrup Urine Disease
  • ➤ branched-chain amino acids
  • ➤ α-keto acids

questions.text: In a study on post-transcriptional gene silencing, an enzyme that processes precursor RNA into short double-stranded fragments was inhibited, leading to gene upregulation. Which of the following enzymes is inhibited?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Dicer

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dicer processes precursor RNA into double-stranded fragments in RNA interference, and its inhibition leads to gene upregulation.
  • ➤ Dicer

questions.text: A molecular biologist is preparing to amplify a specific DNA segment using an enzyme-catalyzed thermocycler-based reaction. Which of the following components, if not included in the reaction mixture, will not affect the amplification process?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) DNA ligase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ DNA ligase is not required for PCR and its absence will not affect the DNA amplification process.
  • ➤ DNA ligase

questions.text: A 45-year-old female on a strict vegetarian diet presents with fatigue, weakness, and pallor. Blood work shows macrocytic anemia. Lab investigations reveal elevated levels of homocysteine and methylmalonic acid. A specific metabolic blockade due to a vitamin deficiency is suspected to underlie her condition, leading to a "trapped" state of a particular molecule. Which of the following combinations best describes the deficient vitamin and the "trapped" molecule in this patient?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Vitamin B12 and 5-methyl THF

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In vitamin B12 deficiency , 5-methyl THF becomes trapped, leading to macrocytic anemia and elevated homocysteine and methylmalonic acid levels.
  • ➤ vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text: A 10-year-old boy came with complaints of anemia, weakness, and a low weight-to-height ratio for his age profile. On examination, the urine sample shows elevated levels of orotic acid. Further study reveals low uridine monophosphate (UMP) synthase activity. What can be the best treatment to administer?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Uridine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The best treatment for orotic aciduria , due to low UMP synthase activity, is administering uridine , which helps synthesize the necessary pyrimidines.
  • ➤ orotic aciduria
  • ➤ uridine

questions.text: A patient presented with pallor and cyanosis with the following presentation (as seen in the image). This condition is most probably due to:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Vitamin B12 deficiency

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 deficiency can lead to knuckle pigmentation, which is often an overlooked but reversible sign of the condition.
  • ➤ Vitamin B12 deficiency

questions.text: A bodybuilder starts eating raw eggs for protein. He developed fatigue during moderate exercise. The doctor prescribes a vitamin. Which enzyme will be negatively affected in him?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pyruvate Carboxylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Biotin (B7) deficiency , caused by consuming raw eggs, affects carboxylase enzymes like pyruvate carboxylase , which plays a key role in gluconeogenesis, potentially leading to hypoglycemia.
  • ➤ Biotin (B7) deficiency
  • ➤ pyruvate carboxylase

questions.text: The point X shown in the following enzyme kinetic plot represents which of the following value?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) -1/Km

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ In a Lineweaver-Burk plot , the x-intercept represents -1/Km , and point X on the graph corresponds to this value.
  • ➤ Lineweaver-Burk plot
  • ➤ -1/Km

questions.text: In glycogen metabolism, a metabolically active important enzyme found in the liver is converted from its inactive dephosphorylated state to its active phosphorylated state. Which of the following is true about this enzyme:

options.label: C
options.text: More commonly seen in fasting state than in fed state

options.label: D
options.text: Always activated by cAMP-dependent protein kinase

questions.correct_answer: C. More commonly seen in fasting state than in fed state
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) More commonly seen in fasting state than in fed state

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Catabolic enzymes in glycogen metabolism are more commonly seen in the fasting state , and their activation is closely linked to phosphorylation, especially through pathways involving cAMP and catecholamines.
  • ➤ more commonly seen in the fasting state

questions.text: The tensile strength of collagen fibers is provided by its triple helical structure, which can be most accurately described as which of the following levels of protein structure?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Quaternary

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Collagen's triple helical structure , formed by three alpha chains, is an example of quaternary structure , providing it with its tensile strength.
  • ➤ triple helical structure
  • ➤ quaternary structure

questions.text: A 30-year-old patient who has consumed street food over the past few days visits a clinic reporting persistent vomiting for the last 3 days. Despite being unable to eat or drink much, his blood glucose level was found to be in the normal range. Which organ primarily played a significant role in maintaining his blood glucose in this situation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Liver

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The liver is responsible for maintaining blood glucose levels during periods of fasting or vomiting by utilizing glycogenolysis and gluconeogenesis.
  • ➤ liver

questions.text: A patient with Type I Diabetes presented with complaints of polyuria. His RQ (Respiratory Quotient) was found to be decreased compared to a normal person. Which of the following will occur in his body?

options.label: D
options.text: Increased conversion of FA (Fatty Acids) to Acetyl CoA

questions.correct_answer: D. Increased conversion of FA (Fatty Acids) to Acetyl CoA
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increased conversion of FA to Acetyl CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In Type I Diabetes , the body shifts to using fatty acids as the primary fuel , leading to an increased conversion of fatty acids to Acetyl CoA through beta oxidation.
  • ➤ Type I Diabetes
  • ➤ fatty acids as the primary fuel
  • ➤ increased conversion of fatty acids to Acetyl CoA

questions.text: A male child presented with coarse facies, protuberant abdomen, frontal head enlargement, thickening of cardiac valves, hepatosplenomegaly, hearing impairment. There was no corneal clouding seen. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hunter’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ The absence of corneal clouding along with the other described features strongly suggests a diagnosis of Hunter’s disease (MPS II).
  • ➤ corneal clouding
  • ➤ Hunter’s disease

questions.text: A 12-month-old infant was brought to the hospital with complaints of screaming after feeding. Removal of milk from the diet did not alleviate the symptoms. All the growth parameters of the child were normal. A liver biopsy analysis reported no enzyme deficiency. Later, a detailed feeding analysis revealed that screaming bouts occurred every time the child was given fruit puree or fruit juice, which immediately caused gas formation and a distended abdomen. Most likely, a biopsy of the patient's intestinal tissue would reveal a deficiency or defect of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) GLUT 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The child’s symptoms of gas and abdominal distension after consuming fruit are likely due to a defect in GLUT 5 , the transporter responsible for fructose absorption.
  • ➤ GLUT 5

questions.text: The graph that follows shows how the concentration of the substrate affects the rate of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction. Which of the following is a false assertion regarding this graph?

options.label: A
options.text: Only a small amount of the enzyme is present as the enzyme-substrate complex at point C

options.label: B
options.text: “?” shown in this graph represents Km of the enzyme

options.label: C
options.text: The shape of the curve is hyperbolic

options.label: D
options.text: Vi is independent of [S] at point C

questions.correct_answer: A. Only a small amount of the enzyme is present as the enzyme-substrate complex at point C
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Only a small amount of the enzyme is present as the enzyme-substrate complex at point C.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In the Michaelis-Menten kinetics, as the reaction approaches Vmax , the enzyme is nearly fully occupied by the substrate, and the velocity is no longer dependent on substrate concentration. Thus, at point C , most of the enzyme exists as an enzyme-substrate complex , making option A the false statement.
  • ➤ Michaelis-Menten
  • ➤ Vmax
  • ➤ point C
  • ➤ enzyme-substrate complex
  • ➤ A

questions.text: Match the following:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) 1-b, 2-c, 3-d, 4-a, 5-e

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Matching diseases with their specific enzyme deficiencies is crucial for diagnosing and understanding the underlying metabolic pathways affected.

questions.text: A strange rash on a child from a refugee camp signals starvation. His parents recall that two of his siblings have the same rash and suffer from a condition known as Hartnup disease. Patients with this condition have a problem absorbing neutral amino acids from their intestines. The doctor told the parents that in this disease, rashes are probably caused by pellagra, which is brought on by niacin deficiency. Which of the following is the reason behind niacin deficiency in Hartnup disease?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Deficiency of tryptophan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The niacin deficiency in Hartnup disease is due to the loss of tryptophan , which is a precursor for niacin synthesis.
  • ➤ Hartnup disease
  • ➤ tryptophan

questions.text: The main complaint of a 40-year-old guy is that he experiences occasional pain in leg and arm during exercise. The cardiovascular illness on his father's side of the family is significant, but not on his mother's side. A physical examination identifies bilateral tendon xanthomas and xanthelasmas. A high LDL/HDL ratio and a cholesterol level of 350 mg/dL are shown by a plasma lipid profile. Simvastatin is prescribed, along with guidelines for dietary changes. Clinical observations made in this patient are most likely the result of inadequate production of?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) ApoB-100 receptors

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: When a nucleotide shown in the figure below is inserted in a growing DNA chain during a PCR reaction, what will happen?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) DNA synthesis stops

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Incorporation of a dideoxynucleotide during DNA synthesis results in termination of the DNA strand , as no further nucleotides can be added.
  • ➤ dideoxynucleotide
  • ➤ termination of the DNA strand

questions.text: A graduate student wants to prepare a genomic library of a human cell line in Escherichia coli cells. For this, she needs to cut plasmid DNA of E. coli as well as human cell DNA with a restriction enzyme that is always known to cut DNA at a palindromic sequence. Which of the following DNA sequences is palindromic in nature that this enzyme might recognize?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) GTGCAC

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ Restriction enzymes recognize palindromic sequences in DNA, and for this example, the sequence GTGCAC fits the criteria of a palindrome.
  • ➤ palindromic sequences
  • ➤ GTGCAC

questions.text: A 2-year-old child displaying bronchitis, persistent cough, and growth failure presents to a doctor. The mother reports that the child has light-colored and foul-smelling feces due to persistent diarrhea. Which of the following vitamin treatments should be taken into consideration?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vitamin A

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of steatorrhea , where fat absorption is impaired, deficiencies in fat-soluble vitamins like Vitamin A should be considered. Vitamin A deficiency can lead to recurrent infections, as seen in this child.
  • ➤ steatorrhea
  • ➤ fat-soluble vitamins
  • ➤ Vitamin A

questions.text: A 27-year-old woman is on a regular prescription of warfarin for the treatment of blood clots. She is planning to become pregnant, so her physician is considering changing her medication to prevent fetal warfarin syndrome, vitamin K deficiency, and potential bleeding episodes in the infant. What biochemical activity might be deficient in the infant if her medication is continued?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) γ-Carboxylation of glutamate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Warfarin inhibits vitamin K , which is essential for γ-carboxylation of glutamate in clotting factors. Continuing warfarin during pregnancy could lead to fetal warfarin syndrome and a deficiency in this critical biochemical activity, potentially causing hemorrhage in the infant.
  • ➤ vitamin K
  • ➤ γ-carboxylation of glutamate
  • ➤ fetal warfarin syndrome

questions.text: A number of proteins are involved in moving iron from intestinal mucosal cells or liver storage into the circulation and delivery to other organs. Which of the following proteins binds to particular cell surface receptors to transfer iron to tissues?
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Transferrin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Transferrin is the protein responsible for binding and transferring iron to tissues through specific cell surface receptors.
  • ➤ Transferrin

questions.text: An 18-year-old girl presents to a clinic with yellow discoloration (jaundice) of the skin, difficulty speaking, poor articulation, and lack of coordination. Ophthalmologic examination shows rusty-brown deposits in the corneas of the eyes as shown in the picture below. Examination of her blood and urine revealed higher than average levels of free copper. She is suffering from which of the following diseases?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Wilson disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wilson disease is characterized by copper accumulation , with key signs like Kayser-Fleischer rings , jaundice , and neurological symptoms.
  • ➤ Wilson disease
  • ➤ copper accumulation
  • ➤ Kayser-Fleischer rings
  • ➤ jaundice

questions.text: A teenager suffering from the deficiency of muscle phosphorylase is getting examined by a rubber ball squeezing test while exercising her forearm. Which of the following statements will be true for this patient compared to a normal person?

options.label: B
options.text: ↑ blood glucose in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

options.label: C
options.text: ↑ blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

options.label: D
options.text: Relatively ↓ blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

questions.correct_answer: D. Relatively ↓ blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Relatively ↓ blood lactate in the blood drawn from the exercising forearm vein

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In McArdle's disease , due to the deficiency of muscle phosphorylase, blood lactate levels do not increase during exercise, leading to relatively decreased blood lactate in comparison to a normal individual.
  • ➤ McArdle's disease
  • ➤ blood lactate levels
  • ➤ relatively decreased blood lactate

questions.text: A young man goes to a clinic and tells the doctor that he feels unwell after eating dairy products, leading to gas, bloating, and diarrhea. When he stops eating dairy, these problems go away. To manage his symptoms, he could benefit from a supplement containing which of the following enzymes?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) β-Galactosidase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objectives:
  • ➤ The enzyme lactase , also known as β-galactosidase , is deficient in individuals with lactose intolerance. Supplementation with β-galactosidase can help manage symptoms when consuming dairy products.
  • ➤ lactase
  • ➤ β-galactosidase

questions.text: A 50-year-old man who drank too much alcohol fell in the street. He was quickly taken to the hospital. What is the first-line treatment to be given to this patient in the ER?
questions.explanation: Ans. A) Vitamin B1

questions.text: Which is not a substrate-level phosphorylation enzyme?
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) PEPCK (Phosphoenolpyruvate Carboxykinase)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ PEPCK is not a substrate-level phosphorylation enzyme, as it utilizes GTP but does not generate ATP or GTP directly.
  • ➤ PEPCK
  • ➤ not

questions.text: A female neonate born full-term who is failing to thrive and not gaining weight is brought to a paediatrician by her parents. Physical examination showed small head, hypotonia, and low muscle mass. Blood examination showed metabolic acidosis with highly elevated levels of pyruvate, lactate, and alanine. A 6-month history also revealed persistent acidosis which did not go away with thiamine supplementation. The enzyme most likely deficient in this patient is:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyruvate dehydrogenase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyruvate dehydrogenase deficiency leads to elevated levels of pyruvate, lactate, and alanine, causing metabolic acidosis that does not resolve with thiamine supplementation.

questions.text: A 42-year-old male presents with complaints of dizziness, weakness, weariness, and shortness of breath. Blood analysis reported a haemoglobin level of 7 g/dl (male's typical Hb levels >13.5 g/dl) and abnormally low lactate in RBCs. In peripheral blood film (PBF), no Heinz bodies were discovered. Which of the following enzyme deficiencies would be the most likely reason for this patient's anemia?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pyruvate kinase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pyruvate kinase deficiency causes hemolysis without the presence of Heinz bodies and is a common cause of hemolytic anemia.

questions.text: All of the following inhibit oxidative phosphorylation except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 2,4 dinitrophenol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ 2,4 dinitrophenol is an uncoupler, allowing oxidation to continue but inhibiting phosphorylation, while inhibitors of electron transport chain complexes block both processes.
  • ➤ 2,4 dinitrophenol

questions.text: The molecule marked by the blue question mark can be all of the following except:
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Acetyl CoA

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Acetyl CoA is not glucogenic and cannot be converted into glucose, unlike pyruvate, lactate, and alanine, which can all participate in cycles that allow conversion back to glucose.
  • ➤ Acetyl CoA

questions.text: A 3-year-old boy presents to the outpatient clinic with a swollen abdomen and failure to thrive. On examination, his liver is palpable 4 cm below the right costal margin, and he has a doll-like face with chubby cheeks. Laboratory investigations reveal fasting hypoglycaemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperuricemia. A liver biopsy demonstrates increased glycogen storage with normal structure. Which enzyme deficiency is most likely responsible for this patient's clinical presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucose-6-phosphatase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (von Gierke’s disease) causes hepatomegaly, fasting hypoglycemia, lactic acidosis, and hyperuricemia, along with increased glycogen storage in the liver.
  • ➤ Glucose-6-phosphatase deficiency (von Gierke’s disease)

questions.text: Muscles cannot use their glycogen due to absence of:
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Glycogen phosphorylase

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle’s disease) prevents muscles from using their stored glycogen for energy, resulting in muscle weakness and exercise intolerance.
  • ➤ Glycogen phosphorylase deficiency (McArdle’s disease)

questions.text: An otherwise healthy 22-year-old man presents to the emergency department with acute onset jaundice and dark urine. He denies any recent illnesses but mentions that he took an over-the-counter medication for fever two days ago. His family history reveals that his maternal grandfather had a similar episode in the past. Peripheral smear shows the presence of Heinz bodies. Which enzyme deficiency is most consistent with this patient's presentation?
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glucose-6-phosphate dehydrogenase (G6PD)

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency leads to hemolysis after exposure to oxidative stress, such as certain medications, and is characterized by the presence of Heinz bodies on a peripheral smear.
  • ➤ G6PD deficiency

questions.text: Which amino acid is responsible for flexibility of proteins:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Glycine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Glycine is the smallest amino acid and plays a key role in protein flexibility by allowing bends in the protein structure.
  • ➤ Glycine

questions.text: Which of the following has a sulfhydryl group:
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Cysteine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Only cysteine contains a sulfhydryl group (-SH) , which is essential for forming disulfide bonds in proteins.
  • ➤ cysteine
  • ➤ sulfhydryl group (-SH)

questions.text: Identify the given structure:
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Adenosine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The structure of adenosine consists of the nitrogenous base adenine attached to a ribose sugar, making it a nucleoside. The absence of phosphate distinguishes it from an adenine nucleotide.
  • ➤ adenosine
